data.title: Ukrainian human rights lawyer, Nobel Prize winner urges Trump to show strength and end the war
data.description: Ukrainian human rights attorney and Nobel Peace Prize winner Oleksandra Matviichuk urges President Trump to show strength as he tries to bring the Russia-Ukraine war to an end.

data.author: Nataliya Vasilyeva
data.title: His Opponents Sidelined, Lukashenko Is Set for a 7th Term in Belarus
data.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, a close ally of Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has been making signs of reaching out to the West. He is all but certain to win an election on Sunday.

data.author: Anton Troianovski
data.title: Putin Dismisses Trump’s Sanctions Threat and Repeats His Stolen Election Claim
data.description: Russia’s president flattered his American counterpart as “smart” and “pragmatic,” and repeated Mr. Trump’s baseless claim that the 2020 election was stolen.

data.title: Ukraine claims drone strike on Russian oil refinery
data.description: Russia says it shot down more than 120 drones overnight, in what would be one of the largest attacks of the war.

data.author: Maria Varenikova
data.title: Ukraine Sends Volley of Drones at Russia, Hitting Oil Refinery
data.description: Videos showed fireballs over a facility in Ryazan, 110 miles southeast of Moscow. Kyiv is seeking to disrupt Russian military logistics and put pressure on the country’s economy by striking its oil industry.

data.author: Choe Sang-Hun
data.title: Trump Says He Will Reach Out to North Korean Leader Kim Jong-un
data.description: North Korea’s leader has grown more assertive since their last efforts at diplomacy ended in failure — and now has Russia at his side.

data.author: Cassandra Vinograd and Maria Varenikova
data.title: Did Ukraine Kill Its Own by Downing a Russian Plane? A Year Later, It Hasn’t Said.
data.description: Russia says Ukraine shot down a military transport carrying 65 captured Ukrainians. Ukraine has not confirmed its role, identified the bodies it received, or said how it happened.

data.title: How Russia's invasion of Ukraine has impacted tennis
data.description: Every sport in Europe -- from soccer to fencing to UFC -- has had to grapple with the fallout of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and tennis is no exception.

data.title: Christopher Eubanks' Wimbledon dream run ends with loss to No. 3 Daniil Medvedev in quarterfinals
data.description: Christopher Eubanks' run at Wimbledon has ended, with the 27-year-old American losing to world No. 3 Daniil Medvedev of Russia in the quarterfinals.

data.title: May 16, 2024 - Russia's war in Ukraine
data.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin has met Chinese leader Xi Jinping in Beijing, emboldened by the survival of his wartime economy and Russia's advances in Ukraine.

data.title: May 14, 2024 - Russia's war in Ukraine
data.description: Antony Blinken met with Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv earlier Tuesday, where the Ukrainian president told the US secretary of state that Ukraine urgently needs more air defenses.

data.author: Charlie Savage, Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
data.title: Kash Patel, Trump’s F.B.I. Pick, Pushed False Claims About Trump Investigations
data.description: Kash Patel, Donald J. Trump’s choice to run the bureau, has made a series of spurious assertions about the Russia, Jan. 6 and classified documents inquiries.

data.author: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Constant Méheut
data.title: Ukraine Is Losing Fewer Soldiers Than Russia — But It’s Still Losing the War
data.description: Russia has lost about twice as many men to death and serious injury as Ukraine. But the trends favor the Kremlin.

data.title: Putin told to end 'ridiculous war' in Ukraine or face new sanctions
data.description: The US president says he is offering Moscow a "big favour" by helping Russia and Ukraine reach a deal.

data.author: Jakub Krupa
data.title: Europe live: Irish parliament tries to confirm Micheál Martin as prime minister after rows in chamber
data.description: Chaotic scenes in the Dáil on Wednesday as parliamentarians clashed over appointing MartinNow, let’s turn to Davos, where several European leaders have been speaking this morning about the prospects for Ukraine in 2025.The Nato secretary general, Mark Rutte, said that allies “have to step up, not scale back the support for Ukraine” as he warned that “the frontline is moving in the wrong direction.”It is not only a European conflict, but a geopolitical conflict, and if we get a bad deal, we will see the president of Russia high-fiving with the leaders of North Korea, Iran, and China...

data.author: Graeme Wearden
data.title: Davos day three: NATO chief Rutte calls for ‘step up’ in support for Ukraine — live updates
data.description: Rolling coverage from the World Economic Forum in DavosThe new US presidential envoy for special missions has pushed back against Mark Rutte’s talk about Ukraine joining Nato, pointing out many members of the alliance aren’t paying their “fair share” already.Richard Grenell, appointed by Donald Trump in December, says it is “pretty shocking” that so many foreign ministers in Europe, and so many American politicians, didn’t try to stop the Russia-Ukraine war, and criticises Joe Biden’s handling of the situation.You cannot ask the American people to expand the umbrella of NATO...

data.author: Graeme Wearden and John Collingridge in Davos
data.title: Keir Starmer urged to push for Ukraine to get $300bn of frozen Russian assets
data.description: Financier turned activist Bill Browder says Russia will make gains that spark refugee crisis if US military support dries upBusiness live – latest updatesKeir Starmer should show leadership over the Ukraine war by pushing for $300bn (£243bn) of frozen Russian assets to be used to fund Kyiv’s military, the financier turned activist Bill Browder has said.Speaking on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Browder warned that if US military support for Ukraine dried up, Russia would make territorial gains in the near-three-year long conflict, forcing millions of Ukrainians to flee...

data.author: Marc Santora and Helene Cooper
data.title: Fighting Alongside Russia, North Koreans Wage Their Own War
data.description: Ukrainian forces described a different kind of enemy, fighting with unfamiliar tactics and little option to retreat.

data.title: As Trump Takes Office, Zelensky Urges Europe to Stand Firm Against Russia
data.description: Speaking a day after Trump’s inauguration, Ukraine’s president told world leaders at Davos that Europe needs to remain united and “learn how to take care of itself.”

data.author: Anton Troianovski
data.title: Trump Says Putin Is ‘Destroying Russia’
data.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia praised President Trump’s second inauguration, but the American leader did not return the compliment.

data.title: Trump Vowed to End the Ukraine War Before Taking Office. The War Rages On.

data.title: U.S. Spy Chief Took on Role of Negotiator in Gaza War

data.author: Cassandra Vinograd and Marc Santora
data.title: Russia Attacks Kyiv With Ballistic Missiles
data.description: A countrywide alert had warned of incoming ballistic missiles. Four of them, and 39 attack drones, were used in the attack, which killed at least four people, officials said.

The UK, one of Ukraine’s biggest military...

data.title: Boulter suffers another early Grand Slam exit

data.title: Poland’s Leader Suggests Russian Hand in Plot to Attack Western Cargo Planes
data.description: “I can only confirm that Russia planned acts of air terror, not just against Poland but against airlines across the globe,” said Poland’s prime minister, Donald Tusk.

data.description: The number of sightings has increased since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, officials say.

data.description: Attacks on underwater cables in strategic areas connecting telecommunication lines and power sources in Asia and Europe are suspected to be coordinated attacks by China and Russia.

data.author: Owen Jones
data.title: Young people are abandoning democracy for dictators. I can understand their despair | Owen Jones
data.description: Fascism in power in the 1930s brought the world to genocidal war. But memories have faded, as has the stigma attached to the far-right – and that’s dangerousDemocracy is dying across the globe. This may sound alarmist and generate a follow-up question: what does that actually mean? Will there be no elections? Will the opposition be criminalised? If these are the metrics, then Vladimir Putin’s Russia remains a democracy. Six political parties are represented in the State Duma, its federal parliament, and there are more than 20 registered political parties. Well, as you probably understand...

data.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukraine ‘captures two North Korean soldiers in Russia’
data.description: Pair being interrogated in Kyiv, with intelligence agency SBU saying one had fake Russian military ID; Russia claims control of village near PokrovskSee all our Ukraine coverageUkraine said it was interrogating two North Korean soldiers after capturing the pair in Russia’s Kursk region – the first time it has announced the capture of North Korean soldiers alive since their entry into the war last year. The president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, said on X on Saturday the soldiers were captured by Ukraine’s special forces and were being interrogated by the SBU domestic intelligence agency in Kyiv...
